overview_metadata.overview_title: Up and Down or Down and Up
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students address the key characteristics of the graphs of quadratic functions and interpret them in terms of a situation. They compare and contrast linear and quadratic relationships. Students use a context to write the equation of a quadratic function. They analyze a function in general form. Students connect how they can write a quadratic function as the product of two linear functions.

overview_item_data_items: I can write and graph quadratic functions to model real-world situations.
I can identify and interpret the key features of quadratic functions in terms of a context.
I can determine the domain and range of quadratic functions and explain their meaning in context.
We can use quadratic functions to model real-world situations.
The graph of a quadratic function is a parabola.
A parabola is a smooth curve with reflectional symmetry.
A parabola has an absolute maximum or an absolute minimum point and an interval where it increases and an interval where it is decreasing.
A parabola has one y-intercept and at most two x-intercepts.
The domain of a quadratic function is the set of all real numbers. The range is a bounded subset of the real numbers based upon the y-coordinate of the absolute maximum or absolute minimum point.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students examine a pattern with a quadratic function.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Using Area to Investigate Quadratic Functions
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students investigate the area of a rectangle and write a quadratic function for the area in terms of width.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Writing and Interpreting a Quadratic Function
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students use a situation to investigate minimum values and explain how to identify a parabola's orientation from its equation.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Using a Quadratic Function to Model Vertical Motion
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students use a context involving vertical motion to explore the roots of quadratic equations.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Expressing a Quadratic Function as the Product of Two Linear Functions
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students analyze a context involving maximizing revenue represented by a quadratic function written as the product of two linear factors.
Students summarize what they have learned about the characteristics of the graph of quadratic functions.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
